body:
Hi All, 

I'm trying to reduce the packaged size of the scientific computing ecosystem to make it friendlier for distributed deployments using tools like docker, kubernetes, etc..  An issue for this topic generally is here: https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/8242

One important issue that came up from @mingwandroid relates to Cython, see https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues/8242#issuecomment-359524128

> It seems the shared libraries are chock full of instruction code

> PyInit_cython_special is huge; more than 1MB.

> why all of these movq instructions are not being coalesced into a memset.

In a separate conversation he said the following:

> Now ideally you'd like your compiler to be smart enough to coalesce all those clears over the whole object into 1 memset, and then even better, put them all together so that a single memset could do it.
> the package size on disk is swamped by the instructions to do these clears!
> instead of a call to a function to memset it's a huge amount of instructions, like tens of thousands.
> and that takes space on the extension module text segment.

To be honest, I don't have much expertise here, but I thought I'd raise an issue here in case this sort of problem can be resolved within Cython, or, if not, if anyone here has any additional helpful thoughts. 

Thank you all for your time.

comment_data.body:
Thanks for bringing this up. As a quick improvement, I enabled `-Os` (optimise for size instead of speed) only for the module init function, and only under gcc for now. For a couple of arbitrarily chosen, -O3 compiled and stripped .py modules, the total .so file size reduction that I could see was 0-3%. So, not useless, but also not impressive. More of a "no reason not to do it" kind of improvement. You can add `-DCYTHON_SMALL_CODE=` to your CFLAGS to disable it and see the difference.

I can't say without further investigation what all those `movq` commands do, but the module init function does a lot of initialisations of various objects, variables and structures. Probably worth taking a look, but it's not necessarily just "stupid code". The C code is most likely easier to analyse than the assembly.

@mingwandroid, would it be possible for you to figure out what generated C code leads to those ``movq`` instructions that were mentioned over in the anaconda ticket? Compiling with debug symbols might give some hints.

I disassembled another module now that I had lying around, and I think those ``movq`` series are simply the initialisation of local (temp) variables. The module init function in question just happens to have many of them. But the size is certainly dominated by the actual code, not the variable initialisation. So this is not an interesting track.

@scoder thank you for spending the time to look into this.  I appreciate it. 

Broadening out my question a bit, it seems like libraries that make heavy use of Cython tend to have large binaries (~10-50MB).  Are there things that can be done from within Cython to improve this situation?

Cython definitely generates a lot of C code and widely uses inline functions that result in even larger assembly code size. That's partly where the performance comes from. I can certainly see an argument for reducing the code optimisation inside of the module init function. I doubt that this would have a measurable negative impact on the import time, and it might even have a positive effect due to smaller modules.

I disabled method unpacking in module level code now, which gives another bit of size reduction, depending on the number of function calls at the module level.

We also considered a special "optimise for size" directive in Cython, but let's face it, you can't beat Python bytecode when it comes to size, so the best you can do if you want small modules is to *not* compile them, or at least not all of their code. (Although, now that I write this - Cython could obviously do that, too, i.e. it could detect longer pure Python code sections in the module init code and output them as interpreted Python code ... Probably not something to implement tonight... And also not to be done lightly, because it would call the Python parser, compiler and interpreter at runtime, which is a huge overhead...)

The new `-Os` optimization seems to have shaved a good bit (~30% AFAIR) from the pandas cython_special init function, but overall it's still pretty large.

For clang `-Oz` is the best flag to pass for space optimization. Should I open an issue about that?

Cool, 30% is a lot, I didn't expect anything in that range.

Regarding clang, is there a compiler directive that would enable this flag locally, as for GCC? The docs that I found last time basically just said "directives in clang tend to be the same as for gcc", but the `optimize()` directive apparently isn't supported, at least by clang 3.8.

If anyone finds such an option for clang, I'd be happy to see a PR that adds it here:

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/bd023b4e4f375ce0c90e85a2bf6302565f9276be/Cython/Utility/ModuleSetupCode.c#L696-L704

Let me try to fact check my 30% at some point though. The overall archive and dso sizes were suspiciously similar, almost as if perhaps inline didn't happen to that function but the stuff that would've been inlined didn't get removed either (because well it's called)? I need to set up a like for like build too and freeze the other moving parts (pandas version etc).

I compared all of Cython's own compiled modules (which are somewhat but not overly diverse in their feature usage) and found that the total size reduction for each of the module files in the latest master branch is a pretty consistent 3-4%. Definitely far from 30%, but I didn't check the separate segments or pure function sizes.

Sorry if this was already asked and I missed this, but is it possible to export a sizeable portion of Cython functionality to say an external shared object (e.g. `libcython.so`) that other packages can depend on? Would understand if not all things can go this way, but would like to find out how much could.
Yes, this idea keeps coming up from time to time. I couldn't find a ticket for it, so I created a new one to keep track of the discussion (#2356).

I spent a little bit of time seeing what adding `-Wl,--strip-all` to `extra_link_args` and `-Os -g0` to `extra_compile_args` of both scikit-image and scikit-learn, libraries that are known to leverage Cython quite heavily.

Adding these flags shaves about 7x off the total size of all of the SOs compiled by scikit-learn. The default compilation triggered by `python setup.py develop` yields a total of 35MB worth of SO files and with those flags the total size is 5MB.

For scikit-image the savings are similarly dramatic. Including debug symbols and using `-O3` instead of `-Os` the total size of all SOs is 58MB, with the above flags the total size is 7.3MB which is a savings of about 8x.

I'm not sure why the default flag of `-g` is included in C extensions, but this isn't a Cython issue per se. We should think about solving this issue for everyone and potentially changing the default, or at least providing a way to easily configure these flags for more complex distutils/setuptools setups (like scikit-image and scikit-learn)

Do you know (or could you find out) what the impact of only `-Os` vs. `-O3` is for these libraries? My guess is that the bulk of the difference in your tests actually came from stripping the libraries, so I would be interested in having real-world numbers only for the result of using `-Os`, as that is more specific to the code that Cython generates.

I don't have the numbers on hand, but I did look at that and it was about a factor of 2 in both cases iirc when just using `-Os`. So it's definitely the case that stripping removed the lion's share of the bulk. There are really two issues here: 1) it's unclear why the ecosystem at large doesn't ship their compiled libraries stripped, and 2) whether optimizing for size is something cython should handle. IMO both should be handled by library authors. Potentially there should be a flag for release and debug modes that is extensible so that folks can customize compiler and linker flags. That's an issue that I will bring up on pypa if it hasn't been brought up already.

>  it's unclear why the ecosystem at large doesn't ship their compiled libraries stripped

When debugging segfaults debug info is very useful, at least being able to see a stack trace at minimum is essential.

I understand why it's useful. C++ libraries have had to deal with this problem long before python existed. I don't think there's anything special about python that necessitates shipping user facing libraries that contain debug symbols.

As someone on the frontline of support when a package segfaults on and end user's machine I disagree. However I do agree that if we had a mechanism in place to split debug info into separate packages and another to make it easy for users to get these installed I'd definitely be interested in persuing that. This is what most Linux distros do with debug info.

There's nothing special about python that *necessitates* it, it's just hugely useful to have that info when there's *any* C or C++ involved (which is the case with `Cython`). I can perform one of the hardest parts of diagnosing problems (where did it crash?) with just that info instead of needing to liaise with the user, make a debug build for them to try, hope it's the same from the perspective of this bug etc, etc.

I have also seen time and time again that stripping saves around 20-30%, while nothing to be sniffed at we're still far from 7x. Can you give exact reproduction steps for arriving at 7x? Are you using conda? conda-forge recipes?

I see two options for stripping:
1. Remove everything except function names.
2. Split the info into a separate package and make it easy for people to install these (but that would still introduce extra round trips of communication with the user in many cases I fear).

Checking in here.  It looks like there is an outstanding question for @cpcloud here::

> Can you give exact reproduction steps for arriving at 7x? Are you using conda? conda-forge recipes?

@mingwandroid I appreciate the need to make debugging smoother.  I also think that shipping around 100MB of debug information for pandas for the occasional bugfix (no matter how deep) is also costly in a few ways.  Obviously there is some tradeoff here to be mindful of in both directions.

My understanding is that shipping debug information by default is not the standard practice, and that instead it's common to include them in additional packages.  Is this possible and likely to happen with our current conda infrastructure?
@mrocklin I will post the steps to reproduce the size gains this weekend.

> My understanding is that shipping debug information by default is not the standard practice, and that instead it's common to include them in additional packages. Is this possible and likely to happen with our current conda infrastructure?

Hopefully someday.

title: Large output size of compiled code
